  95. Bug24618: Improve explanation of the relationship of the xsl:analyze-string instruction and the new analyze-stringFO30 function.

  96. Bug24619: Introduce shadow attributes (static AVTs) allowing any XSLT attribute to be statically computed during preprocessing.

  97. Bug24621: Remove incorrect notes concerning dynamic evaluation of current-group and current-grouping-key.

  98. Bug24649: A construct cannot be guaranteed streamable unless it is declared streamable.

  99. Bug24651: Change the streamability rules for accumulator-before and accumulator-after.

  100. Bug24679: Make streamable stylesheet functions work in more cases.

  101. Bug24690: Correct use of the term initial named template.

  102. Bug24726: Renames the map:new function as map:merge, and introduces map:put.

  103. Bug24744: Reinstate definition of the map:size function which had been accidentally deleted.

  104. Bug24763: Rephrase a number of error conditions so that referential and uniqueness rules apply within a package, not a stylesheet.

  105. Bug24764: Remove confusion between the global context item and the initial match selection, in particular by replacing xsl:mode/xsl:context-item with xsl:package/xsl:global-context-item.

  106. Bug24864: Error XTDE0060 is absorbed into error XTDE0700.

  107. Bug24970: Use the term core function only in the way it is formally defined.

  108. Bug25000: Supplying an incorrect value for a key in a map expression is a type error not a dynamic error.

  109. Bug25158: Add error case when the default value of a parameter to xsl:iterate is invalid. (This small technical change triggered a substantial editorial reorganization of section 9.2 Parameters.)

  110. Bug25160: Change the mechanism for assessing the streamability of expressions such as section//head; instead of an early rewrite of such expressions into a different form, the streamability rules for relative path expressions have been extended to handle the concept of "scanning expressions".

  111. Bug25173: Provide a new function stream-available to test whether a document is available for streaming.

  112. Bug25174: Provide an option recoverable="no" to avoid the costs of buffering result trees for try/catch recovery.

  113. Bug25185: Atomization of crawling expressions is now allowed: for example <xsl:value-of select=".//title"/>.

  114. Bug25196: Define xml-to-json as an ordinary function, with the XSLT stylesheet becoming an illustrative implementation..

  115. Bug25316: Recognize expressions such as (//x)[$i+1] as striding rather than crawling.

  116. Bug25327: Add further examples to illustrate the effect of the general streamability rules.

  117. Bug25335: Rewrite the rules for streamed merging so that the selected nodes are snapshotted.

  118. Bug25350: Editorial corrections and improvements to a streamability example.

  119. Bug25364: Editorial corrections to a streamability example.

  120. Bug25375: Maps cannot contain a mix of values with timezones and values without timezones.

  121. Bug25517: Clarify the meaning of the xsl:mode/@typed attribute, and add an error condition.

  122. Bug25611: Disallow reference to the global context item from within a library package.

  123. Bug25679: Allow stylesheet functions to be declared as streamable and to be invoked from streamed templates.

  124. Bug25701: Update references in bibliography.

  125. Bug25821: Recognize that a template or function is grounded if its as attribute specifies an atomic type.

  126. Bug26268: The initial-value expression of an accumulator is evaluated with the root node of the streamed input as context item, not with the global context item.

  127. Bug26289: Correct a nonsensical statement concerning the use of $value in the new-value expression (now select expression) of an accumulator rule.

  128. Bug26308: Allow true and false as synonyms of yes and no.

  129. Bug26328: Clarify the rules for the use of accumulator-before and accumulator-after with streamed nodes.

  130. Bug26330: Generalize the definition of accumulators, especially xsl:accumulator/@applies-to, to work with non-document input trees.

  131. Bug26378: Rework examples to align with the latest streamability rules.

  132. Bug26422: Extend the definition of the term package so that it includes implicit packages.

  133. Bug26438: The new xsl:package/@declared-modes attribute controls whether implicit mode declarations are permitted.

  134. Bug26439: Improve the streamability of the functions fold-leftFO30, for-eachFO30, and for-each-pairFO30.

  135. Bug26443: The syntax for package versions and version ranges has been revised to conform with industry practice.

  136. Bug26467: Fixed an editorial ambiguity regarding xsl:global-context-item.

  137. Bug26468: An xsl:stylesheet element no longer appears as a child of xsl:package; instead the top-level declarations can appear as children of xsl:package.

  138. Bug26471: Replace the new-value attribute of xsl:accumulator-rule with a select attribute or the option of a contained sequence constructor.

  139. Bug26477: Allocate an error code for the situation where xsl:use-package fails to resolve.

  140. Bug26543: The requirement to report a circularity overrides the usual rule that dynamic errors in patterns are masked.

  141. Bug26525: Text value templates are recognized within xsl:text if enabled using expand-text.

  142. Bug26559: The function map:for-each-entry is renamed map:for-each

  143. Bug26648: The semantics for comparing package versions refer to XPath rules for edge cases such as overflow.

  144. Bug26649: Introduced EBNF to define the package version syntax.

  145. Bug26679: Corrected the descriptions of errors XTSE3020 and XTSE3030.

  146. Bug26737: Editorial corrections and non-normative advice concerning accumulators.

  147. Bug26740: Disallow xsl:param/@visibility attribute.

  148. Bug26742: Delete obsolete references to the existence of preceding-sibling counters.

  149. Bug26752: Improve the streamability rules for quantified expressions.

  150. Bug26780: Clarify the meaning of the version attribute on xsl:package.

  151. Bug26781: Change the interaction of xsl:expose with the visibility attribute on component declarations.

M Incompatibilities with XSLT 2.0 (Non-Normative)

This section lists all known incompatibilities with XSLT 2.0, that is, situations where a stylesheet that is error-free according to the XSLT 2.0 specification and where all elements have an effective version of 2.0 or less, will produce different results depending on whether it is run under an XSLT 2.0 processor or an XSLT 3.0 processor.

  1. XSLT 2.0 gave implementations freedom what to do when a node selected by xsl:apply-templates matched more than one template rule. XSLT 3.0 is more prescriptive in this situation. The behavior prescribed in XSLT 3.0 (selecting the template rule that is last in declaration order) is compatible with the action of some XSLT 2.0 processors but not necessarily others.

  2. It is now a static error if the same NameTest appears in both an xsl:strip-space and an xsl:preserve-space declaration with the same precedence and priority. Previously this was a dynamic error, and processors were allowed to recover from the error.

  3. The current group and current grouping key are now absent rather than empty when not in use, which means that attempting to refer to them in this state gives a dynamic error.

  4. As a consequence of functions such as format-dateFO30 moving from this specification to [Functions and Operators], error codes associated with these functions have changed.

  5. The concept of recoverable dynamic errors has been dropped. Of the remaining recoverable dynamic errors, some are no longer errors, and others are now situations where the behavior of the processor is implementation-dependent. Error codes of the form XTREnnnn have been renumbered XTDEnnnn.

  6. In previous versions of the specification, the element-available function when applied to names in the XSLT namespace was defined to return false in the case of XSLT elements other than instructions. (Actual practice in implementations was not always consistent with this rule). In XSLT 3.0 the rules have been changed so that it returns true for the names of such elements, bringing the specification of the function into line with the intuitive meaning of its name.

  7. (This is not strictly speaking an incompatibility, as conforming XSLT 2.0 stylesheets will continue to function correctly without error. It can be considered as migration advice, a warning that care is needed when introducing new XSLT 3.0 features.)

    When a function or template has a parameter with a declared type of item(), it should not assume (as it could in XSLT 2.0) that when the supplied item is not a node, it must be an atomic value, and vice versa. In XSLT 3.0 there is a third option: it might be a function. Functions and templates that fail to cater for this possibility may fail with a type error if the caller supplies a function as the relevant parameter value.

  8. XSLT 1.0 and 2.0 required the grouping-size attribute of xsl:number to be a "number" (a term which in other contexts was defined to mean any decimal value), but no interpretation was provided for non-integer values. XSLT 3.0 requires the value to be an integer.
